posts.cooked:
There were plenty of mechanisms over the past few years where a CIM or BAG or Mini-CIM could have been used effectively, but due to weight constraints, a brushless motor was necessary.

Level the playing field once again, let’s invest $20 for a motor now instead of being at a significant disadvantage—especially concerning robot weight—and ensure fairness in competition.

The image shows a motor controller with dimensions 313×144 pixels and a file size of approximately 4.81 KB.

Remember, the motor must be connected via a breaker slot, and the motor controller itself contributes to the overall weight.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: The tradeoff is PDH/PDB slots.

posts.name: Ryan Dognaux
posts.cooked: Pretty neat idea. If the weight limit stays at 115, maybe this could be a way to allow 125 lb robots with up to 10 lbs brushed motors in use. I could see some innovative ways teams could push the envelope while creating an incentive to reuse the plethora of brushed motors many teams have.

posts.name: Yuval Gur | Electronics & Software mentor
posts.cooked: Maybe motors should only count as 75% of their actual weight because if they're not counted at all, teams might start using them as dead weight just to exploit the rules.

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked: Honesty I enjoy the design trade-offs and discussions they could create for teams. But how would you suggest this be enforced easily during inspections Also how would you ensure teams aren’t installing brushed motors on their robots for free ballast

because if they’re not counted at all, teams might start using them as dead weight just to exploit the rules. Only up to the # of available breaker slots. If a team managed to use 10 extra CIMs instead of 10 Kraken x44’s, that’s an additional ~25 lbs? Could always cap the “free weight” at ~10 lb, so robots never end up over 125 lbs.

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
Instead of "put your robot on the scale. Weigh it," we'd be "Put your robot on the scale. Which brushless motors do you have? Let me look in the chart for how much they weigh, do some math…"

And then you have people who use brushless motors for ballast—do they count or not?

It’s probably helpful to understand why there’s a weight limit. Part of it is just to put a constraint—to make teams make choices—and that’s part of what engineering is. But part of it is safety-related, and part of it is because we don’t want 150-lb behemoths running around the field.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Pretty neat idea. If the weight limit remains constant at 115 pounds, perhaps this could offer a solution for allowing 125-pound robots to use up to 10 pounds of brushed motors. Teams might explore creative ways to innovate while encouraging the reuse of readily available brushed motors among many teams. Additionally, the sticking point here is the maximum robot weight limit, which exists primarily for safety concerns. Therefore, it’s not feasible to simply 'give away' additional weight.
Count the brushless motors of each type connected to a PDH slot, each type has a known weight, subtract that from the measured weight.
That is almost certainly one of the reasons but I think it's a good rule regardless as design tradeoffs are a good thing to have in a game.

These are eminently solvable problems. Instead of "put your robot on the scale," we'd be "which brushless motors do you have?" Let me look up the chart, calculate the weight,… No math in our STEM competition! Do they count brushless motors for ballast? Could cap the "free weight" at ~10 lb, keeping robots under 125 lbs. Count the brushless motors of each type connected to PDH slots, subtract their weight from the measured weight.

posts.name: Ryan Dognaux
posts.cooked: Fair point, we should probably avoid giving these kids back issues.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked: The initial motor allowance for lower resource teams has been reduced from 10 pounds to maintain a safer buffer.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
If you stuck with last year’s rule of 115 lbs you could do the 10 lb idea and make the lifting moot  
But what is the benefit here? The cost argument really isn’t convincing to me  
The number of mechanisms on a robot that don’t need a location motor are usually pretty small  
Intake rollers come to mind  
But on our last robot that would be the only location where I would freely give away the built in encoder  
And are many people really struggling to stay under weight while using all the PDH locations especially with CTRE’s PDH2

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: Every team using a brushed motor gets a refund on the cost of one Kraken motor from their season registration fee. This initiative, known as the "recycle/reuse" program, is supported by an environmental organization.

But what is the benefit here? The cost argument really isn’t convincing to me. The number of mechanisms on a robot that don’t need a location motor are usually pretty small.

Maybe your team needs built-in internal encoders on everything, but many teams are running intakes, winches, serializers without using the built-in encoders, and for things like arms teams often use an external sensor anyway.

Reducing the cost of 10% of the robots in the program by potentially $300 by using two CIMs where a team would have otherwise used Kraken modules seems low cost, high reward.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked: I’ll bite on the winking emoji, :wink:. Interesting thought! I kind of think the cost savings makes it easier to afford registrations anyway, if that wasn’t the goal in the first place. They’ve sent out these motors in the KOP Kit of Parts, or they’re on FIRST Choice, which is very affordable. I’m not sure we could ask our finance-strapped mothership to subsidize a design choice more than they already are. Recycling older motors could put you in line for a sustainability award, so there’s another benefit.

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked: The number of teams taking advantage of this rule change does not justify the added complexities it introduces. Additionally, since the robot is now heavier, it becomes significantly harder to lift, and there are concerns about student safety while performing such tasks.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked:
**Cleaned-Up Text:**

Or just teach them how to lift properly

posts.name: fargus111111111
posts.cooked: It’s a fun idea but I’m still more a proponent of limiting the quantity of big expensive motors used just by count.

data.title: Brushed Motors shouldn't count towards the weight limit
